text: Protein kinase inhibitor H-7 blocks accumulation of unspliced mRNA of human T-cell leukemia virus type I ( HTLV-I ) .

<extra_id_0> Rex <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , the post - transcriptional regulator of human T-cell leukemia virus type I ( HTLV-I ) , is known to induce accumulation of the unspliced viral <extra_id_0> gag <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> pol <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA .
<extra_id_0> Rex <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a phosphoprotein found in the cell nucleolus , whose function may be regulated by its localization and phosphorylation .

We have examined the role of phosphorylation on <extra_id_0> Rex <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> function by using a protein kinase inhibitor , H-7 [ 1 - ( 5-isoquinolinyl-sulfonyl ) - 2-methylpiperazine ] .

Treatment of an HTLV-I infected human T-cell line with H-7 blocked specifically accumulation of the unspliced <extra_id_0> gag <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> pol <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , resulting in the decreased <extra_id_0> Gag <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein synthesis that corresponds with the decreased in vivo phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> Rex <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
In contrast , other viral and cellular products have not been influenced by the level of H-7 used .
Therefore , the phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> Rex <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required for the viral RNA partition of HTLV-I .
